element_texts.text: Completed

crossed out  2  As you know I am writing to lay before you a plan to increase the social value of the country papers
2)
I want to get at a typical case of sorts. It should be emphasized that I bought two papers, not one.
1)

I have talked to you of my plan to call attention to their field. I think these country papers might be made a real cultural influence, a force for decency. I want to start some

propoganda to this end. I have unclear any  plans for doing this. I want to tell you also, rather in detail, of my own experience,
Completed
The weekly is handed about from neighbor to neighbor.   Subscribers, after reading, mail it to relatives.
Completed

11
established and a well organized propaganda began to show young men and women the possibilities of this field.

I have myself done what I can in this matter. Already a good many young men write to me [ crossed out:  [about the matter. If not myself -]]  Some man I heard begin going about and lecturing on the subject in schools and colleges calling attention to the country newspaper field as a possibility.
 Those who are already in should be encouraged. It is ?2 unclear words? of your Mr  Alexander  to go to a state meeting of those country editors.  As you will see by the attached article on this subject I believe that crossed out the country papers have in so many cases got into the hands of second
Completed

12
rate men because of the city ? movement that they for so  long a time drained off the brighter young men and women.

 There are however young men and women already in the field and they like the work.
 However they feel isolated. They should be brought together in some sort of spiritual cause.   I myself think two things should be done, first pecuniary and ? wants provided

and to get better men and women into the field, ensuring its ? and then all of  the men and women now are made to feel they are a part of  some thing.

 The whole thing should be built on broad cultural
Completed

13
lines, as force for discovery - a possible force for discovery being developed.
Completed

[[[letterhead]]    THE ROYALTON     44 West Forty Fourth Street   NEW YORK
Feb 2  40
Dear Florence V Anderson -

 Your letter delighted me. Now you must arrange that I have a photograph of the Maine Sherwood  to hang in my Virginia house.
 I am taking the liberty of sending one for him - a fair trade.   I will be at the above address until spring.  In the summer

I live in the Mountains of Southwest Virginia.  My best to Thenas?

   Sherwood Anderson

symbol of NY World's Fair  footnote to letterhead "Visit the World's Fair - New York"
Completed

letterhead  THE ROYALTON   44 West Forty Fourth Street   New York


    Nov - 26  - 40

Dear Reverend Anderson

 The boys sometimes called me Andy. However the name given me, in my Ohio town

when I was a boy and by which I was almost altogether known until
I grew up and left the town was Jobby.

 I presume it was because I was always after any job that came up in the town.
 Good fortune to you  I was delighted to get your letter.
             Sherwood Anderson

symbol of NY World's Fair  footnote to letterhead  "Visit the New York World's Fair in 1940"
Completed

E?  Apr 25, 1932 in pencil
Dear Valenti Angelo

 There is more I wanted to say to you. I think their notion - of going to the factories for more ? experiences is so much the word? of the future.
 I had the conception myself, long ago and tried to express it in Machinery Men  but later got swept aside from it.  I had some success.  Perhaps that poisoned me.
 The pictures and the?  must be the new road.
 I think artists in all fields must follow this  road now and am very happy that your foot is in the stirrup.  Keep it there now. Keep exclusively your own close contact 

with men  at work in factories and the machines they handle
Completed

2
man. It is the way of the  new man.

 There is something personal. There is a woman here with whom I am in love.

It is not known that I am in love with her. She is a working woman, concerned
now with women and girls in factories. At present she has  a job in the industrial
department of a philanthropic organization. She is about 35, rather small and
dark, with a big head, like your own child and with eyes like your child.  I would
like to have a head made of her, for a present to her old father and mother. Would
it be possible. How much would it cost? How much time would it be likely to take?
Completed

3
I have to ask because she does not have much time away from her work.

 I am particularly anxious not to have talk about my being in love with her
 It might actually cause her to lose her job -
 We will be married later but I dont want that known either.
   When a man becomes a little what is called famous there are too many 

who dabble in his personal life.

 Anyway I would like to have you see her and see how you feel about

trying to make a head of her.

   Sincerely
   Sherwood Anderson
Completed

Dear Angelo

 Eleanor & I are married and living for the winter in New York at 56 Washington Mews.*
 When you get here drop me a line 

have to L & G.

 Sherwood Anderson

* a private street
Completed

Dear Valenti .

 I just got back to New York, after an absence and got the 

announcement of yours then. Unfortunately I have to go to
West Virginia tonight.

I'll be back before the show closes.  I'm anxious to see it.
  Sincerely
 Sherwood Anderson
Completed

letterhead  Ripshin Farm  Troutdale, VA.
Saturday
Dear Alice.
What a grand letter. No, Alice I did not know what you told me. I once had some such an experience myself, of which I will some day tell you.
We make a bid now for you to come to us next summer. You are such a lovely person. I have written Randolph to tell him that he would never get a chance at you but that I love my Eleanor. Do write, from time to time. You made us love you.
I had to write Glover, telling him I did not want
Completed

letterhead   RIPSHIN FARM  TROUTDALE, VA.
him to unclear. on the proposed book.   He may be too young for it and then I may do it later myself, in some other form.
However do not speak of my having said this to you. 
With my love,
Sherwood
Give my love to Virginia and the others when you are again in Olivet?.
Completed

letterhead  THE ROYALTON  44 WEST FORTY-FOURTH STREET NEW YORK
Tuesday
Dear Alice
I am here in New York with Eleanor still in Marion, trying to settle up her Mother's affairs.  It was a pretty unsuccessful Christmas.

 Alice we did both appreciate your lovely greet and I am embarrassed we have not thanked you sooner.
  I hope we may 2 unclear words whether or not we will have to abandon our trip.
 I do hope you had a happy visit here.

Love
Sherwood Anderson
Completed

n.d.
My Dear Mary Austin.

 I have been for some months at the steps of the desert and have found your books.   They have been such a relief to me after all the other books of the mountain country I have read.  What Terrain and Hants? missed your News Journal and set down with such fine understanding.
 The books have been a real joy to me.

Sincerely
Sherwood Anderson
Mail address.
℅ Max Radin
2597 Buena Vista Way.
Berkeley 
Calif.
Completed

Dear Mary Austin -

  Perhaps I had to be for a time out in the west before I could know the people and things you write about.   I shall look up American Rhythm the next time I am in some place where the book may be had.   I may see you before I leave the west - but when that may be I do not know.
  I like particularly your own writing about wandering people and there was one thing of yours called the Field I loved very much.
  Do not be annoyed that I have been so long finding you out - will you.   I am such a long time finding anything out.
Completed

Jacques Copeau and several others have tried to get me interested in writing drama but whenever I go to the theater I shudder at the notion.   ? I fancy myself that anything I have to give ? be given as a tale teller as much as any other way.   God knows I have yet enough to learn about that.

  I am sorry you have been ill.   Have been myself recovering from nerves.  They go along more steadily now.  You may be sure I shall write you when I have got my hand on The American Rhythm.
  May I thank both Mabel Lujan Luhan? and yourself for the invitation to come in and see you.  I may, one of these days, be wandering past.

Sincerely
Sherwood Anderson
Completed

Dear Mary Austin -                                        n.d.

 I know it is too bad of me. I'm an awful writer 

about such things. Do forgive me and be assured I'll always
be glad to take the responsibility of anything you say.

 I shall see you some day,
     Sincerely,
     Sherwood Anderson
Completed

n.d.
My Dear Mrs Mary Austin -

 I am sure I know nothing at all of this matter and to tell the

truth know very little of literary clubs.

 Anyway I am sure that what ever you may do will have my

approval.

 Will you therefore go ahead with my O.K.  A committee of one is the only

effective sort anyway.

  Sincerely
    Sherwood Anderson
Completed

Chicago  Dec 3 - 1921.
circled in right margin  see over
My Dear  Mr John Eakins
And Franklin H Giddings.
The Authors Club
Seventh Ave & 56th Street
New York

 I should be delighted, I'm

sure, to be a member of the
Author's Club. If after my
name is presented you want
me let me know what I
will be owing. - A Non-Resident Membership.

 Thanking you sincerely
 Sherwood Anderson
Completed

letterhead  RIPSHIN FARM  Troutdale, VA.   Winter Address     Marion, VA.
June 14 1939

Dear Emily.
 I have been intending to write you ever since I got home.

You were so very nice to us in Mexico and it was so
delightful seeing you there. -

 What are your plans? What are you doing? Are you coming

home this summer.

 We would be so delighted to see you here, on our farm,

here in the hills. You meant much to us, tell us
your news.

 As for our selves, when we got home Eleanor went

off to New York while
Completed

letterhead  RIPSHIN FARM   Troutdale, VA.    Winter Address         Marion, VA.

 I stayed in Marion to work, but about ten days 

ago, we got our house opened and here we are 
for the summer.

 And it is seriously a very grand summer, everything very

green and growing? and the nights cool and pleasant. I

hope you are coming to America this summer and

that we shall see you.

We both send love.
  Sherwood Anderson
Completed

in pencil Nov 6'39
The Canterbury - San Francisco.
Dear Judge - Monte* - Dorothy

 How  you have made me

love you.  It is wicked. I'll 
pay you out by making you
try to read my scrawl. It 
has sent others to the insane
asylum, why not you?

You are all so darned beautiful.
 Brigham Young was right.
 I want to marry you Monte
 I want to marry you Dorothy
 I cant make make such a proposal to the judge.
 I'm not working on that side of the street.
   I'm a mystic about

Monte is a daughter of the Judge (Sherwood's writing often looks like Mante)
Completed

2
people. They always either 
poison you or they giving? you 
new health -

 You all do that  fast to me and very beautifully.
 I kept wanting to ?ay you all.
 We'll be here about two weeks and then at the

Hotel Figuero, Los Angeles.

  I do hope we will see you all there.
Love - a plenty
 Sherwood
Completed

in pencil in top margin Bartletts
letterhead  RIPSHIN FARM   Troutdale, VA.

Dec 26 - 39
Dear Judge, Monte, Dorothy -

 We got home from one long trip on the day before

Christmas and both of us agreed that the thaest? visit
we had at your house was about top of the trip.

 How I wish we could have stayed on.
Monte - many thanks for your thoughtfullness in sending

us the Rilke. I  hope you have forgiven me. 

 Judge - please remember that I want your picture to hang in
Completed

RIPSHIN FARM 
Troutdale, VA.

Winter Address
Marion, VA.

my house. Wes Popler sent me a fine one of Han. When it is
so long between deni?s with the men friends I most admire
I like a picture of them hanging where I cam get a daily look.

 Have they - Job - the Judge about his picture. When we

were in San Antonio Eleanor got some dope to send you
about the beautification of the eauec? there. She'll be sending
it to you.

 Have to go all. I wish I were in your house right now.
  Sherwood Anderson
Completed

We both went to Robert Coche's? house  What a lovely woman he has got. She seemed very

fine and beautiful to us both.

 And what a beautiful woman Dorothy is. She stays so very sharply in my mind.
 I am glad you are launched? in the book. If you can think and recite? just

about the people who have come and gone tell it will be wonderful.

 Again love to you all.
Completed

If you will take back the nasty suggestion of your letter and stacyments? 

we and  may go to the Pioneer Hotel - Tucson. Ariz.

 If you still feel I am the impossible ass the letter suggests, forget it.
Completed

   Jan 6 - 39 -crossed out  40
Dear Monte
 A salute to the Judge and to the beautiful Dorothy.
 Monte I cant in any way figure out how you could think that

anything in your letter could possibly offend me.  Perhaps I did
think that - crossed out after reading the little poem that it would
be nice if I could take the place, temporarily, of the tall?, between
you and the star.

 Your anaer? about me,
Completed

instead of the tall?, etc.

 Does Dorothy ever do any such star gazing.  I

might come out.

 As it is we are still westward bound, to West Virginia

and then New York. We will be, for the next 2 or 3 months
at Hotel Royalton - 44 West 44 St.

 I think you might all enjoy my piece in the next? Readers Digest.
 I didn't go so strong for Rilke - nan, an?  I

perhaps take your Jan Aldus Huxley's
Los Angeles. That lads a nice fellow but too  damn clever... Rilke

to attennated for me.

 Had a nice Ohrman? sed from Mrs? Popler. She sent me a 

personal? picture of Dan.

 Love to all of you,
Do come to see us if any of you come to New York.
  Sherwood.
Completed

[[in pencil:  Bartlett [?]  1940]]

Dear Monte.
 Well, I think your poem for the post or the papers. It is beautiful.
 I am at Wa?ts all my Memories - a general task that I love doing  It is grand fun.
  Sometime Monte, when you and young ? y all

must come to see us here. You would love the hills.

 Now, ? we will be closing the house. Eleanor will go to New York at the end of

the month and I will move into Marion where I have a swell apartment, staying
Completed

2
there until November 1st.

 I was go to South America the winter.
 Please do send my best to Gene and be?

Wayland?. I'll make it a point to call there
when I get in New York.

 And all my love to the Judge and Dorothy.
 Love also to you
  Sherwood A.
Completed

Dear Monte.
 As I know very little - (really nothing) of the Actniqus

of  verse making I must stand aside on it.

 Once I had a conversation with Henry  Mencken - He had been writing about poetry.
 "I really know nothing about poetry" he said
  Me - "Then why the hell do you write about it?
  Menk - laughing - "Oh, hell, I don't know. Its a lusivrr - Lucifer? with me."
   You are right in thinking I wouldn't particularly like Lucifer's Angels.  I
Completed

did like very much Familiar Fruit.

 Eleanor has gone to New York but I stay w here, at waet? The

Country is Oh so beautiful now.

 I have to go to Detroit & Ann Arbor at the end of November. 

I wont get to New York until after the Putnams have gone.

 Love to all of you Ubres?.
   Sherwood
Completed

 All eny? At Monte but you must know, my

dear, that I cannot thank

 You see Monte I am quite grown up and

have been about in this American literary
world a long time. I don't want the Weeks?

want me.  I have no desire to be a tail to that Kite.

 Oh Monte, why would you?

 If you were here I would spank you most soundly?.

in pencil:  13  2p.         Bartlett   Nov 7  40
THE ROYALTON
44 West Forty-Fourth Street
New York

 Thursday

Dear Monte

  I called the Putnams but they had checked out at the Carlyle.  Too bad.

I was delayed as I had to go out of Town. How I would have liked much to see them.

 Well, Monte, the hullabaloo is over here and the city news strangely quiet now

that? the election campaign is over.

 I guess we'll all live on - no? mull.. which was ??.. fun.
Completed

2

44 West Forty-Fourth Street
New York
Ted Weeks at Atlantic called up and wants me
to go on the air with him on the evening of
the 19th

 I guess I will.
 Just the same Monte I'm not so  happy

being in the city, rather than in my own? hills.

 Give a wave for me to Judge & to Dorothy.
   Love
Sherwood A

and to the yas? O Dan

 I am afraid dear Monte that the   

program will not prove very exciting... and
I do not know at just what ?  it
causes me. All I know is that it is on Tuesday
evening and from Radio City..  a 17 minute talk
about life in American small towns with Ted Weeks

 Sherwood.

in pencil in top margin  Bartlett  Dec 28 '40
letterhead  PRIVATE OFFICE    HOTEL FARRAGUT    KNOXVILLE, TENN.
Saturday
Dear Monte -
We came home to a sad Christmas.  Eleanor's mother a very beautiful and remarkable woman, we all loved, had been found dead in her bed.
It is a grand way to die and she was old and tired but something inside her never had tired.  Her death wrecked us.
Monte dear, your confession of love is the finest Christmas gift I could have.  I shall hang it up on a peg in my inner mind
Completed

letterhead  PRIVATE OFFICE    HOTEL FARRAGUT    KNOXVILLE, TENN.
2
But you must be very beautiful?  I insist upon that.

Once, in New York, when you came into the room, very slender and smart, in a little black hat, you were the most beautiful I had seen you.

What a lucky man, the judge, to have two beautiful daughters.
I must send you all one of my new books.  I will, as soon as I am ? from N.Y.
Love to you and the others too

   S.A.
Completed

in right margin in pencil Release EA May 2' 75
Dear Barton -

 I have sent you some more scenes of the play  - as they form themselves in my mind and will go right on with it. I hope, by the time you have got your new play produced, we may have it in such working? I hope that you can come down here and we can thrash it out - scene by scene.
 I do not think we need worry about following the details of lives in Winesburg too carefully. What difference does it make what becomes of Doctor Parcival - whether Seth 

Richmonds father
Completed

2
dies or lives.

 As I conceive the play there is - as the theme - the two boys - Seth and George - the whole difference in their outlook on life - Seth the careful shrewd self-centered boy and George the imaginative, lovable one.
 The points of view of the father and mother and their struggle for the boy's mind -
 This to become the central theme of the play.
 Then the struggle of the two boys for Helen White.
 You can't pack Winesburg into a neat hand package
Completed

3
Barton.

 The whole question about the interduction of characters - Doctor Parcival, Joe Welling and other is as to whether they bely develope the whole feel of the drama.
 I don't want a hard sharp smooth story one I believe we can get plenty of intensity and feeling without it.
 But any way I will plow right on and hope to be ready for you when you are ready.
 Sherwood Anderson
Completed

P.S.

 It has occurred to me that you may not want me to do what I am doing - that is to say going right ahead in this way and putting down my own conception of these people. the story - the play.
 If you would rather I didn't send the scenes to you as I go through them leaving your own revised stories from your own conception - I  won't
 Write and tell me about this -
     S.A.
